title: Madness lead singer Suggs says he loved being a football hooligan
text:

Madness lead singer Suggs has confessed he loved going to football games for the thrill of violence.

The Chelsea fan, 58, claimed he loved aggro at London derbies against Charlton, West Ham and Millwall.

He described going to watch his team play as a "thrill" when going in a huge group surrounded by his mates.

Suggs told the Daily Star: "When I say it was a thrill, it was a terrifying thrill, because you could just bump into anyone, anywhere."

Confessing how a pal dodged their group from getting caught up in a fight, he said: "One time, going to the old Den at Millwall, with Chalky, he had the great foresight to go, 'Let's not go in the away end. Let's go in the Millwall end. Hide your scarf.'"

(Image: Getty Images)

He then explained that once the game had finished and you'd get on the tube, there'd be a roar coming from around the corner and you didn't know who it was - referring to fans of the opposite team.

(Image: Ken McKay/ITV/REX)

Suggs, real name Graham McPherson, said he'd hope there wasn't enough of the rival fans to be able to beat him up.

The singer also referred to the hooliganism as the Battle of Agincourt.

(Image: Mirrorpix)

(Image: EMPICS Entertainment)

He confessed: "Then, there'd be a volley of Coca-Cola cans from the upturned hot-dog stall, knocking the coppers off their bucking horses. It was like Agincourt."

(Image: Getty Images)

And Suggs also admitted he was stealing from charity shop Oxfam at around the same time a pal suggested they start a band, saying: "You'd go in the cubicle, take the clothes, put them on under what you were wearing and walk out."

He also revealed he and a friend were still committing crime in London at the time Madness were first on the show.
description: Suggs, 58, has confessed he loved going to football games for the thrill of violence in his younger days
